The main goal here is to make people able to interact in a realistic 
context. So, if we have those huge megacitites, we better have some people 
with whom to speak. I guess you understand this.

What I suggest is this: we classify NPCs in categories. Civilians, police, 
military, scientific, diplomatic and government, Watchers, traders, 
industrials, Corrupt (mafia-like), Cyberworld, and so-on. After that, we 
hand out those categories for the players to be in charge of. So, when 
Boybot wants to investigate on a slug that was used to kill a High Diplomat, 
he either goes to see a scientist (controlled by Tankor, for example) or a 
gun expert investigator (controlled by someone else). These are the minor 
NPCs, those you'll meet once or twice and forget about.

Of course, there are going to be major NPCs too. I think we can handle them 
with the categories, and the players could also control them, with a few 
exceptions. The major NPCs are not characters and are thus killable. Sergent 
Roughbot, Maximal unit leader, may get in intense combat along with the unit 
the PCs are in, but while the players' chars will get out of the fight 
alive, Sarge will be killed by the frag grenade that hit too close. Also, 
there must be no more than 1 or 2 major NPCs by category, meaning that they 
are both extremely rare and extremely valuable to the roleplaying 
experience. Optionaly, the major NPCs could be dictated or partly dictated, 
meaning that the design (or not all of it)  will not be left to the player. 
This last point is more debatable because it's simply boring to have nothing 
to invent, but it could also be simpler. Another point about Majors: They 
have to make the story progress in some way. Sarge up there died, but his 
death is taken as a declaration of war by the Silver Wings and they simply 
start an assault on Pred units because of this.

I send this to everybody because it will be simpler to explain in this way 
and also I want to hear comments, suggestions and corrections about this.
